Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: I glanced at my phone, reading the message from Mark, an acquaintance from my book club. “Hey, could you help me move a few boxes this morning? I’m really in a bind.” I knew he didn’t have many people to call on, and I’d always believed in being there for others when they needed a hand. That’s what friends—or even acquaintances—do, right? But as I typed out a reply, my eyes flicked to the clock. My volunteer shift at the community food pantry started in less than an hour. I was the only one scheduled to open up today, and I knew people would already be waiting outside, counting on me to unlock the doors and get things started. The thought of letting them down made my stomach twist. I wanted to help Mark, but I also couldn’t bear the idea of leaving those families standing in the cold. My mind raced, torn between the expectation to support someone who’d reached out and the responsibility I’d committed to as a volunteer. I stared at my phone, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, unsure which way to turn.
